items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: The Flood Alert for the River Foulness and Market Weighton is no longer in force as river levels have fallen. Further rain is forecast for Sunday 23/10/2022. We will continue to monitor the situation and may re-issue this alert if conditions worsen.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts.

The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Loughborough urban watercourses and local tributaries to the River Soar
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further significant rainfall is forecast today, 22/10/2022.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Ray and Swinbourne for West Swindon area to above Water Eaton
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Today will remain dry for most places. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We will be clearing debris from weed/trash screens across the area in anticipation of further potentially heavy rainfall tomorrow.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Today will remain dry for most places. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We will be clearing debris from weed/trash screens across the area in anticipation of further potentially heavy rainfall tomorrow.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

Flooding is possible - be prepared
Small, flashier rivers and streams like the River Wey may respond to heavy rainfall passing through the area in the early hours of Sunday 23/10/22. This message has been issued pre-emptively ahead of potential localised heavy rainfall between 04:00 AM on 23/10/22 and 06:00 AM on 23/10/22. Given the unpredictable nature of the rain storm, there is low confidence in the locations and impacts of rainfall at this point. Areas most at risk are low lying agricultural land, roads and footpaths close to small rivers and streams. Water levels could rise rapidly and potentially generate deep, fast flows.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/10/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the upper River Wey as a result of localised thunderstorms. Flooding of low lying footpaths, roads and farmland is possible tomorrow morning, 23/10/22, especially in the Bordon area, if the heavier showers occur. 
Thunderstorms are forecast in the early hours of Sunday morning and then again during Sunday afternoon, and showers may become organised into bands of rain. However there is low confidence over exact timing and locations. Once the risk of thunderstorms has passed on Sunday evening, 23/10/22, we expect river levels to begin falling, but levels do remain sensitive to further rainfall. 
Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed screens. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow, 23/10/22, by 11:00, or as the situation changes.
